Iron deficiency anemia is a condition where the body does not have enough iron to produce hemoglobin. Ferritin, TIBC, serum iron, and transferrin saturation are all related to iron metabolism and blood production. Looking at each option, we see that ferritin, which stores iron for use by cells, would likely increase if there was enough iron available. TIBC and serum iron are both related to the amount of iron available in the bloodstream, so they would also likely increase if there was sufficient iron.

The only option left is transferrin saturation, which measures how well transferrin is being used to carry iron. If there is too much iron available, transferrin saturation would decrease as the body becomes less dependent on transferrin to carry that excess iron.
